title: lmhelprs
text: time writing, lmhelprs two sets functions: hierarchical_lm() ordering linear regression models hierarchical way use anova() compare . test_highest() identify highest order term linear regression model compare model model term removed.

title: lmhelprs
text: Users can use anova() manually hierarchical regression. hierarchical_lm() written features: Check whether models really “hierarchical”. yes, order automatically. Users need put correct order manually. Compute R-squared R-squared change add output. Let’s fit three models illustration: can passed hierarchical_lm() order. Hierarchical regression analysis conducted correctly, R-squared R-squared change: models hierarchical order, error raised: Please refer help page hierarchical_lm() works, print method output (print.hierarchical_lm()) customize printout.
code: library(lmhelprs) data(data_test1) lm1a <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2, data_test1) lm1b <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4, data_test1) lm1c <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 + cat2, data_test1) hierarchical_lm(lm1b, lm1a, lm1c) #> Analysis of Variance Table #>  #> Model 1: y ~ x1 + x2 #> Model 2: y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 #> Model 3: y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 + cat2 #>   adj.R.sq   R.sq R.sq.change Res.Df   RSS Df Sum of Sq      F Pr(>F)     #> 1   0.5090 0.5189     0.00000     97 55.83                                #> 2   0.7269 0.7380     0.21906     95 30.41  2    25.419 39.314 <0.001 *** #> 3   0.7242 0.7437     0.00573     92 29.74  3     0.665  0.686  0.563     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 lm2a <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2, data_test1) lm2b <- lm(y ~ x1 + x3 + x4, data_test1) hierarchical_lm(lm2a, lm2b) #> Error in hierarchical_lm(lm2a, lm2b): The models do not have hierarchical relations.

title: lmhelprs
text: linear regression model term second higher order, function test_highest() can used identify highest order term, compare model model term removed, estimate test R-squared increase due adding term. example: Although six product terms, terms variables, one higher order term: cat2:cat1, interaction cat2 cat1. automatically find term, compare model model without interaction, test_highest() can used: R-squared change due adding interaction (represented six product terms) model without interaction 0.02633, p-value change 0.567. function test_highest() can used third higher order term. example: model three-way interaction compared model two-way interactions (x3:x4, x3:cat2, x4:cat2). model one term highest order, error raised: Please refer help page test_highest() works,

title: Helper Functions for Linear Model Analysis
text: tasks covered sometimes needed using manymome package (Cheung & Cheung, 2023) stdmod package (Cheung, Cheung, Lau, Hui, Vong, 2022). Therefore, ready, two packages make use functions lmhelprs. However, functions can also used scenarios. Therefore, named lmhelprs.

(2023). manymome: R package computing indirect effects, conditional effects, conditional indirect effects, standardized unstandardized, bootstrap confidence intervals, many (though ) models. title: Sample Data: For Testing — data_test1
text: eight-variable dataset 100 cases.

title: Sample Data: For Testing — data_test1
text: data frame 100 rows 8 variables: x1 Predictor. Numeric. x2 Predictor. Numeric. x3 Predictor. Numeric. x4 Predictor. Numeric. x5 Predictor. Numeric. y Outcome. Numeric. cat1 Predictor. String. Values: "Alpha", "Beta", "Gamma" cat2 Predictor. String. Values: "North", "South", "East", "West"

title: Sample Data: For Testing — data_test1
code: data(data_test1) lm(y ~ x1 + cat2 + cat1 + cat2:cat1, data_test1) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x1 + cat2 + cat1 + cat2:cat1, data = data_test1) #>  #> Coefficients: #>         (Intercept)                   x1            cat2North   #>           -0.099251             0.655101            -0.510542   #>           cat2South             cat2West             cat1Beta   #>           -0.062337            -0.070097             0.003442   #>           cat1Gamma   cat2North:cat1Beta   cat2South:cat1Beta   #>            0.026172            -0.011252            -0.475115   #>   cat2West:cat1Beta  cat2North:cat1Gamma  cat2South:cat1Gamma   #>            0.140028             0.136924             0.564488   #>  cat2West:cat1Gamma   #>            0.246710   #>

title: Check Models Hierarchy — hierarchical
text: extracts terms model stats::terms() extracts labels terms labels(). labels used determine hierarchical order. Therefore, principle, function can used outputs model fitting functions long outputs support stats::terms() labels can used determine hierarchical order two models.

title: Check Models Hierarchy — hierarchical
text: Shu Fai Cheung https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9871-9448

title: Check Models Hierarchy — hierarchical
code: dat <- data_test1 lm1 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2, dat) lm2 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4, dat) lm3 <- lm(y ~ x1 + cat1 + cat2 + x2 + x3 + x4, dat) lm4 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2*x3 + x4, dat)  # The order of entry does not matter hierarchical(lm1, lm4, lm2) #> [[1]] #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x1 + x2, data = dat) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)           x1           x2   #>     -0.1231       0.6016       0.2797   #>  #>  #> [[2]] #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4, data = dat) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)           x1           x2           x3           x4   #>    -0.04715      0.41484      0.27693      0.35712      0.36060   #>  #>  #> [[3]] #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 * x3 + x4, data = dat) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)           x1           x2           x3           x4        x2:x3   #>    -0.04627      0.41504      0.27698      0.35490      0.35950     -0.01706   #>  #>   # The following three models yield NA hierarchical(lm3, lm4, lm2) #> [1] NA

title: Hierarchical Regression Analysis — hierarchical_lm
text: conducted hierarchical regression analysis two models fitted stats::lm(). models must able ordered simplest complex, complex model formed adding one terms simpler model. ANOVA conducted compare model next complex model order, R-squared change computed.

title: Hierarchical Regression Analysis — hierarchical_lm
text: Shu Fai Cheung https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9871-9448

title: Hierarchical Regression Analysis — hierarchical_lm
code: dat <- data_test1 lm1 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2, dat) lm2 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4, dat) lm3 <- lm(y ~ x1 + cat1 + cat2 + x2 + x3 + x4, dat) lm4 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2*x3 + x4, dat)  hierarchical_lm(lm1, lm3, lm2) #> Analysis of Variance Table #>  #> Model 1: y ~ x1 + x2 #> Model 2: y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 #> Model 3: y ~ x1 + cat1 + cat2 + x2 + x3 + x4 #>   adj.R.sq   R.sq R.sq.change Res.Df   RSS Df Sum of Sq      F Pr(>F)     #> 1   0.5090 0.5189     0.00000     97 55.83                                #> 2   0.7269 0.7380     0.21906     95 30.41  2    25.419 39.717 <0.001 *** #> 3   0.7270 0.7518     0.01385     90 28.80  5     1.607  1.004   0.42     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 hierarchical_lm(lm1, lm2, lm4) #> Analysis of Variance Table #>  #> Model 1: y ~ x1 + x2 #> Model 2: y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 #> Model 3: y ~ x1 + x2 * x3 + x4 #>   adj.R.sq   R.sq R.sq.change Res.Df   RSS Df Sum of Sq      F Pr(>F)     #> 1   0.5090 0.5189      0.0000     97 55.83                                #> 2   0.7269 0.7380      0.2191     95 30.41  2    25.419 39.320 <0.001 *** #> 3   0.7242 0.7382      0.0002     94 30.38  1     0.024  0.073  0.787     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 # The following models will yield an error message: tryCatch(hierarchical_lm(lm1, lm3, lm2, lm4), error = function(e) e) #> <simpleError in hierarchical_lm(lm1, lm3, lm2, lm4): The models do not have hierarchical relations.>

what: Convert a 'lm_list' Object To a Parameter Table — lm_list_to_partable
title: Convert a 'lm_list' Object To a Parameter Table — lm_list_to_partable
text: Convert output many_lm() lavann-style parameter table.

title: Convert a 'lm_list' Object To a Parameter Table — lm_list_to_partable
code: lm_list_to_partable(   object,   keep_intercepts = FALSE,   vcov_args = list(),   pvalue_fun = NULL,   rsquare = FALSE )

title: Convert a 'lm_list' Object To a Parameter Table — lm_list_to_partable
text: object output many_lm() manymome::lm2list(). keep_intercepts Logical. TRUE, intercepts regression models means "pure" predictors (variables outcome variables regression models) kept parameter table. FALSE, default, intercepts means removed. vcov_args named list arguments passed stats::vcov() computing standard errors regression coefficients. Default list(), empty list. pvalue_fun function used compute p-values regression coefficients. Ignored now. Included adding feature future. rsquare Logical. Whether R-squares included output, r2 operator column op. Default FALSE. included default semPlot::semPaths() draw R-squares residual variances.

title: Convert a 'lm_list' Object To a Parameter Table — lm_list_to_partable
text: data frame object columns lhs, op, rhs, est, major columns output lavaan::parameterTable() necessary plotting model using semPlot::semPaths().

title: Convert a 'lm_list' Object To a Parameter Table — lm_list_to_partable
text: function convert lit lm objects, output many_lm() manymome::lm2list(), table parameter estimates similar output lavaan::parameterTable. output designed used semPlot::semPaths() contains information necessary plot.

title: Convert a 'lm_list' Object To a Parameter Table — lm_list_to_partable
text: Shu Fai Cheung https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9871-9448

what: Fit Linear Models Defined By Model Syntax — many_lm

text: Fit list linear models defined model syntax.

title: Fit Linear Models Defined By Model Syntax — many_lm
Fit Linear Models Defined By Model Syntax — many_lm
text: models Character. Model syntax. See Details. data data frame. Must supplied na_omit_all TRUE. na_omit_all FALSE, can omitted (though suggested). na_omit_all missing data handled across models. TRUE, default, cases missing data variables used least one models retained (.e., listwise deletion). FALSE, missing data handled model separately lm(). subset specified, ... Additional arguments. passed lm().

title: Fit Linear Models Defined By Model Syntax — many_lm
text: list output lm(). class lm_list_lmhelprs.

title: Fit Linear Models Defined By Model Syntax — many_lm
text: function extracts linear model formulas model syntax (character vector), fits lm(), stores results list. Lines first non-whitespace character "#" treated comments ignored. line must valid formula lm().

title: Fit Linear Models Defined By Model Syntax — many_lm
text: na_omit_all TRUE, default, cases missing data least one variables used model removed. call lm() subset set integer vector cases removed (.e., cases retained)

title: Fit Linear Models Defined By Model Syntax — many_lm
text: subset used calling function, also used select cases. Note subset argument call model replaced numeric vector cases retained, determined missing data original value subset.

title: Print a hierarchial_lm Class Object — print.hierarchical_lm
code: # S3 method for class 'hierarchical_lm' print(   x,   digits = 4,   signif.stars = getOption("show.signif.stars"),   eps.Pvalue = 0.001,   ... )

title: Print a hierarchial_lm Class Object — print.hierarchical_lm
text: x hierarchical_lm-class object, usually output hierarchical_lm(). digits minimum number significant digits used numbers. used print method anova-class objects. signif.stars Logical. used print method anova-class objects. eps.Pvalue passed format.pval(). controls small p-values displayed. Default .001. , p-values less .001 displayed <.001. ... Optional arguments. passed print method anova-class objects.

title: Print a hierarchial_lm Class Object — print.hierarchical_lm
text: x returned invisibly. Called side effect.

title: Print a hierarchial_lm Class Object — print.hierarchical_lm
text: printout similar print method anova object. simply overrides default values arguments, notably esp.Pvalue prevent small p-values presented scientific notation.

title: Print an lm_list_lmhelprs-Class Object — print.lm_list_lmhelprs
code: data(data_test1) mod <- "x3 ~ x2 + x1         x4 ~ x3         x5 ~ x4*x1" out <- many_lm(mod, data_test1) out #>  #> The models: #> x3 ~ x2 + x1 #> <environment: 0x55c34c0cff70> #> x4 ~ x3 #> <environment: 0x55c34c0cff70> #> x5 ~ x4 * x1 #> <environment: 0x55c34c0cff70> #>

what: Test the Highest Order Term by ANOVA — test_highest
title: Test the Highest Order Term by ANOVA — test_highest
text: Identify highest order terms model fitted 'lm()', compare model model term removed using ANOVA.

title: Test the Highest Order Term by ANOVA — test_highest
Test the Highest Order Term by ANOVA — test_highest
text: lm_out output stats::lm().

title: Test the Highest Order Term by ANOVA — test_highest
text: hierarchical_lm-class object, output hierarchical_lm(). Two models compared, original model model unique highest order term removed.

title: Test the Highest Order Term by ANOVA — test_highest
text: function test_highest() first check model fitted stats::lm() unique highest order term (e.g., term x1:x2, model y ~ x1 + x2 + x1:x2). yes, fit model term removed, call hierarchical_lm() compare original model reduced model. model unique highest order term, error raised.

title: Test the Highest Order Term by ANOVA — test_highest
text: test_highest(): Test highest order term. highest_order(): Find highest order term.

title: Test the Highest Order Term by ANOVA — test_highest
text: relies terms created stats::lm() determine order term. higher order term created manually (e.g., (x1 * x2)), know term second order term.

title: Test the Highest Order Term by ANOVA — test_highest
text: Shu Fai Cheung https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9871-9448

title: Test the Highest Order Term by ANOVA — test_highest
code: dat <- data_test1  lm1 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2 + cat1*x3, dat) lm2 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2*x3 + x4, dat)  test_highest(lm1) #> Analysis of Variance Table #>  #> Model 1: y ~ x1 + x2 + cat1 + x3 #> Model 2: y ~ x1 + x2 + cat1 * x3 #>   adj.R.sq   R.sq R.sq.change Res.Df   RSS Df Sum of Sq     F Pr(>F) #> 1   0.6517 0.6693   0.0000000     94 38.37                           #> 2   0.6446 0.6698   0.0004711     92 38.32  2   0.05466 0.066  0.937 test_highest(lm2) #> Analysis of Variance Table #>  #> Model 1: y ~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 #> Model 2: y ~ x1 + x2 * x3 + x4 #>   adj.R.sq   R.sq R.sq.change Res.Df   RSS Df Sum of Sq     F Pr(>F) #> 1   0.7269 0.7380   0.0000000     95 30.41                           #> 2   0.7242 0.7382   0.0002041     94 30.38  1   0.02368 0.073  0.787  highest_order(lm1) #> [1] "cat1:x3" highest_order(lm2) #> [1] "x2:x3"  # The followings will yield an error  lm3 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2 + x3, dat) summary(lm3) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 + x3, data = dat) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -1.1889 -0.3990 -0.0022  0.4116  1.5963  #>  #> Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept) -0.08776    0.06515  -1.347    0.181     #> x1           0.44060    0.06905   6.381 6.20e-09 *** #> x2           0.30064    0.06013   5.000 2.58e-06 *** #> x3           0.42361    0.06804   6.226 1.26e-08 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 0.6436 on 96 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.6573,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.6466  #> F-statistic: 61.37 on 3 and 96 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16 #>  tryCatch(test_highest(lm3), error = function(e) e) #> <simpleError in highest_order(lm_out): No unique highest order term.> tryCatch(highest_order(lm3), error = function(e) e) #> <simpleError in highest_order(lm3): No unique highest order term.>  lm4 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2*x3 + x4*x5, dat) summary(lm4) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 * x3 + x4 * x5, data = dat) #>  #> Residuals: #>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max  #> -1.00627 -0.31572  0.03453  0.30428  1.29839  #>  #> Coefficients: #>              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept) -0.012917   0.048049  -0.269 0.788661     #> x1           0.363822   0.049985   7.279 1.11e-10 *** #> x2           0.180795   0.045679   3.958 0.000149 *** #> x3           0.296156   0.050633   5.849 7.49e-08 *** #> x4           0.324834   0.054432   5.968 4.44e-08 *** #> x5           0.346000   0.049278   7.021 3.69e-10 *** #> x2:x3        0.009253   0.051784   0.179 0.858572     #> x4:x5       -0.072788   0.069142  -1.053 0.295221     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 0.4589 on 92 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.833,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.8203  #> F-statistic: 65.56 on 7 and 92 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16 #>  tryCatch(test_highest(lm4), error = function(e) e) #> <simpleError in highest_order(lm_out): No unique highest order term.> tryCatch(highest_order(lm4), error = function(e) e) #> <simpleError in highest_order(lm4): No unique highest order term.>

title: lmhelprs 0.3.0.2
text: many_lm() now properly support subset. (0.3.0.1) print-method summary() many_lm() output now prints cases removed, . (0.3.0.1) Added lm_list_to_partable() converted list lm() outputs data frame similar output lavaan::parameterTable(), can used semPlot::semPaths() draw path model fitted several regression models. (0.3.0.2)

title: lmhelprs 0.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-02-18

title: lmhelprs 0.3.0
text: Added many_lm(). (0.2.0.2, 0.2.0.3) Added internal checks hierarchical_lm() check whether two models fitted identical dataset. (0.2.0.4)

title: lmhelprs 0.3.0
text: Added logo. (0.2.0.5)

title: lmhelprs 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-10-30 Added data_test1, test dataset. (0.0.0.9002) Added hierarchical(). (0.0.0.9003) Added hierarchical_lm() print method output. (0.0.0.9004, 0.0.0.9005, 0.0.0.9006) Added test_highest() highest_order(). (0.0.0.9007) Added vignetted. (0.0.0.9008) First submission CRAN. (0.1.0, 0.2.0)
